text: so the the main idea the main way that
we did this study was we uh imaged
people in the scanner before and after
48 hours of sleep deprivation and one of
the primary tasks we used was the one
that I just described I I'll I'll say it
again people saw one three or six
letters uh for a few seconds they waited
7 Seconds a probe letter came up and
they had to um uh decide whether that
was one of the letters that had been
presented to them so we gave them the
exact same task pre and post and what we
found behaviorally was that people were
slower uh and sometimes maybe 20% of the
time they didn't respond within the time
limit and then we imaged them with fmri
while they were doing that and we could
look during the stimulus phase or the
retention phase or the probe phase when
they saw the letters while they were
retaining the letters or when we asked
them is that one that you saw um what
was going on in their brain the way that
we approach looking at data is a little
different than other labs so what we do
is first of all we're interested in what
changes from pre- to posts sleep
deprivation and we look at the brain as
a whole rather than looking at one
particular area of the brain we try to
find a set of brain areas that are
working
together uh H and um we call that a
network it's not a network like like a
neuro physiologist would a one neuron
wired to another to another but but
because it's a set of areas that work
together we call it a network so we're
looking looking for a brain Network that
uh reduced its uh activity from pre-
toost sleep deprivation and the other
thing we're interested in is could we
find a network that that where that
happened in every single person and the
thing that we were hoping for is if we
found such a network that the people who
did worse after sleep deprivation would
show more of a loss in the use of that
Network than the others and that's
that's what we identified so we
identified this brain Network so some of
the areas that were uh the areas that
showed reduced activation were in the
back of the head some occipital areas
and some parietal areas some of the
areas that sort of maintained activation
or sometimes increased with sleep
deprivation because sort of like a
fulcrum this network uh we're towards
the front of the head um and um so we
identified this network that the more it
reduced its activation from pre- to post
sleep deprivation those people who who
showed more of a reduction were the ones
who did the worst so in a sense we we
solved the first problem we found
something in the brain that was going on
in the brain that was associated with
differential susceptibility to sleep
deprivation
um that that was already quite in
advance no one had
really had a a handle on that the truth
is that it's very hard if you just look
at someone or talk to them to predict
whether they can handle sleep
deprivation well or not no matter what
they tell you then what we try to do is
say
okay are we just seeing something
Imaging or is it something that really
has to do with people's behavior and
that's where we use the transcranial
magnetic stimulation so the idea was
that with with TMS depending on the what
what you're doing is giving these pulses
of magnetism pretty intense uh you can
focus what area of the brain that you uh
put it on and depending on the frequency
you can either stimulate that area or
inhibit function in that area so we
picked an area that showed reduction
posts sleep deprivation and we tried to
stimulated and Our Hope was that if we
stimulated that area we could improve
people's
performance and we focused on those the
the occipital and the the the occipital
and the parietal areas that were that
seemed to show the most reduction and
what we found which was surprising to me
is that first of all the stimulation to
the occipital area did help people
respond a little
faster uh compared to some other area
that had nothing to do with the network
and the people who benefited most from
that stimulation were the people who had
showed the most reduction in the
network which which is another
confirmation that we were finding
something interesting so I found that
quite surprising now it's not a it's not
a cure for sleep deprivation it was only
while we were stimulating and uh while
they were performing that task um you
know so to imagine let's say you could
really bring that into real life you
know you you'd have to imagine like a
truck driver who's very sleepy having a
magnetic stimulator on there head so I
don't think it's really very practical
but um it was an idea of showing that we
we have this brain network uh maybe we
could intervene in other ways the kind
of things that we thought about if we
were to continue that line of research
would be maybe we could train people
using feedback to um actually using a
kind of neuro bio feedback to actually
use that Network more effectively so if
they were feeling tired maybe they could
actually by themselves upregulate that
Network then the the the final
experiment that we did was even um more
dramatic um what we did is we did the
exact same thing we we sleep to Pride
people for 48 hours but twice a day
during the two days of sleep deprivation
they did this memory task that I
described and they got stimulation to
that brain area while they were doing
the memory task uh and some people got
that stimulation and some were in a like
a placebo group they didn't get it and
we're overall we didn't see a huge
difference between this TM treat it was
like a drug study really but using TMS
we didn't see a uh huge differences
between the the treated group and the
untreated group but on some very
specific measures we did see some
differential Improvement in the uh TMS
group and why that's interesting is that
we were the the post testing wasn't done
while they were getting TMS so there was
a more long-term relationship so perhaps
getting that four sessions of
stimulation actually helped these people
regulate this network a a little
better
